results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia

results.title: Swarm
results.brief_description:
Sound and image projection specifically commissioned for Eyes Lies and Illusions in 2006.

Multi-site work using projection and audio to create the illusion that a swarm of insects live in the gallery ceiling.

results.title: Type 2014K Image Orthicon camera
results.creator_credit: Films & Equipment Ltd., Vinten and PYE Ltd.
results.brief_description: Pye cameras were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

constellations_primary.name: News on location
constellations_primary.description: The Pye Orthicon is an example of the type of television cameras used from the 1950s in Australia for both studio and outside broadcast work. Such cameras did not have have the capacity to record while out on location and so outside crews would transmit vision and sound back to studios for recording or live broadcast.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Films & Equipment Ltd., Vinten and PYE Ltd.
results.description:
In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.
description_for_label:
In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Street XRays
results.brief_description:
Drawing on the NSW Police Department’s photographic archive, Street X-Rays interprets approximately sixty crime scenes from the 1950s, to evoke the power of the continuing life of the past in our ordinary, everyday places.

The police images are placed beside contemporary footage recorded in the same location, from the same camera position. Each screen holds two moments in time, two disparate attempts to interrogate a location. Texts from police records and the artist’s enigmatic narrative prompts punctuate this essentially visual dialogue. The effects of time linger in each scene and across the entire imaginative space of this half-historical/half-mythical city that is evoked in the installation space.

I’ve tried to conjure a place that’s haunted by persistent little pulses of history. I hope viewers feel as if they’ve wandered into a vaguely familiar ‘otherworld’ that’s being buffeted by a kind of ‘spirit weather’ - Ross Gibson.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.
